subject: Is China inventing big important things?
body:
View this post on the web at https://www.noahpinion.blog/p/is-china-inventing-big-important

â€œWe are amazed, but not amusedâ€ â€” Stevie Wonder
Writing about Trumpâ€™s chaos every day is exhausting. Iâ€™ll get back to it tomorrow, but today Iâ€™d like to take a short break to write about a civilization that isnâ€™t currently tearing itself apart and accelerating its own decline: China. 
The 20th century had a bunch of rising powers that all reached their peaks in terms not just of relative military might and economic strength, but of technological and cultural innovation. These included the United States, Japan, Germany, and Russia. So far, the 21st century is a little different, because only one major civilization is hitting its peak [ https://substack.com/redirect/3390192b-2c82-4ae5-a64f-5ffe8da9b44b?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] right now: China. All the old powers are declining, and India is just beginning to hit its stride. 
Chinaâ€™s peak is truly spectacular [ https://substack.com/redirect/6d0aceae-f239-4e14-8769-e37880973a78?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] â€” a marvel of state capacity and resource mobilization never seen before on this planet.  In just a few years, China built more high-speed rail than all other countries in the world combined. Its auto manufacturers are leapfrogging the developed world, seizing leadership in the EV industry of the future. China has produced so many solar panels and batteries that it has driven down the cost to be competitive with fossil fuels â€” a huge blow against climate change, despite all of Chinaâ€™s massive coal emissions, and a victory for global energy abundance. Chinaâ€™s cities are marvels of scale â€” forests of towering skyscrapers lit up with LEDs, cavernous malls filled with amazing restaurants and shops selling every possible modern convenience for cheap, vast highways and huge train stations. Even Chinaâ€™s policy mistakes and authoritarian overreaches inspire awe and dread â€” Zero Covid failed in the end, but it demonstrated an ability to control society down to the granular level that the Soviets would have envied. 
But itâ€™s still an open question whether China will be as creative as the great civilizations of the 20th century. Many people (including myself [ https://substack.com/redirect/e85431a1-b0c0-4ed2-8da2-caa98a6211a8?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]) compare early 21st century China to early 20th century America [ https://substack.com/redirect/2224b82f-c8db-4afa-a8ef-94d072ab0bd5?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. But by the start of World War 1, Americans had already invented the airplane, the light bulb, the telephone, the record player, air conditioning, the automatic transmission, the machine gun, and the ballpoint pen. And the country had already given rise to jazz music, Hollywood movies, and lots of well-known literature. Japanâ€™s cultural explosion came a bit later [ https://substack.com/redirect/0e29549a-ae6a-4310-a38e-41643d542160?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], but was every bit as impressive.
Itâ€™s pretty obvious that an autocratic, repressive government stifles cultural creativity. I still expect Chinaâ€™s cultural exports and influence to increase as time goes on, due to increased personal wealth and leisure time that make Chinese people feel more free to pursue artistic interests. But everything in the country is heavily censored [ https://substack.com/redirect/b6b8a5c0-fa57-4e82-9742-b260439637eb?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], which means that the movies [ https://substack.com/redirect/af6275ce-da04-49c9-a49e-0ba07a9f2502?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] and music and video games [ https://substack.com/redirect/c1bb6b83-7f40-48b7-bacb-b3887f1c2923?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] and TV and art that come out of China will usually tend to be bland, anodyne stuff. 
Itâ€™s much less clear whether scientific and technological creativity suffers from autocracy, though. Autocrats want to develop science and technology to make their countries strong. They sometimes squelch private entrepreneurs out of fear that an alternative center of power would threaten their rule, but at the same time they tend to direct large amounts of resources toward research and development. The USSR beat the U.S. to space (twice), and Germany was pretty autocratic for most of its run as the worldâ€™s leading scientific and technological powerhouse. 
Modern China is certainly a very innovative country. Chinese scientists now publish the majority of high-impact papers in fields like chemistry, physics, computer science, materials science, and engineering:
The countryâ€™s true dominance is probably less than depicted in this chart, due to â€œhome biasâ€ in the citations [ https://substack.com/redirect/9eada355-5ced-4979-9f56-f4a9aa4fe267?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] used to measure papersâ€™ impact. But even correcting for that bias, China is undeniably a scientific superpower.
Chinaâ€™s innovation outside of the laboratory is just as impressive. A vast number of incremental improvements [ https://substack.com/redirect/993bbbcf-9b3e-41e6-bfe2-826ab4ef06e0?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] and process innovations [ https://substack.com/redirect/8325861f-ecb1-4e13-8577-5b69e25134ff?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] allow many Chinese businesses to improve product quality and decrease manufacturing cost much more effectively than their foreign rivals. Without Chinese innovation, most of the manufactured goods we consume would be either lower-quality, more expensive, or both. In fact, Chinese companies are responsible for most of the nationâ€™s research spending [ https://substack.com/redirect/4726a5a2-548b-4e84-9f1d-15298f929a92?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. As a result, Chinese companies dominate the global market for a number of high-tech products:
And in terms of deploying technologies so that people can use them, China is now ahead of most or all of the rest of the world. It has the worldâ€™s biggest high-speed rail system, one of the worldâ€™s best 5g cell phone networks [ https://substack.com/redirect/fd81b0ad-7efe-4cd9-8a1d-2afbbc2f07ef?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], the worldâ€™s best mobile payments system, the worldâ€™s best delivery robots [ https://substack.com/redirect/0d62275c-a357-46ab-befc-78b7f2b960e3?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], some of the worldâ€™s most automated factories [ https://substack.com/redirect/b3c8689d-9aa5-429f-836f-428e8c20a2ba?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], and the worldâ€™s most futuristic cars [ https://substack.com/redirect/81e11e61-9313-4ff1-a3ba-93862b883ddb?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ].
But in terms of actual big scientific and technological breakthroughs â€” game-changing inventions, theories, and empirical findings â€” what has China produced in its golden age so far? The answer to this question might not be economically important â€” itâ€™s hard to name an invention that came out of Singapore, and yet itâ€™s among the richest countries on Earth. But itâ€™s kind of an interesting question nonetheless. 
Now, some people argue that big breakthroughs are just less common than they used to be. Some believe the low-hanging fruit of science has already been picked [ https://substack.com/redirect/b1121b2b-1789-41b4-9b91-981a39cc2d71?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. Itâ€™s also possible that the much greater competitiveness of todayâ€™s global scientific enterprise and todayâ€™s global economy mean that itâ€™s harder for a single inventor or discoverer to get far ahead of the pack. Nevertheless, we have seen a bunch of big breakthroughs and game-changing inventions in the last two decades â€” AI, generative AI, mRNA vaccines, Crispr, smartphones, reusable rockets, lab-grown meat, self-driving cars, and so on. And itâ€™s usually not too hard to identify a few researchers or a single company that made the big breakthrough for each one of these. 
So what big ones have come out of China in the last decade and a half? First of all, I think itâ€™s helpful to differentiate three different types of breakthrough innovation:
Scientific discovery: This is when someone either finds some important empirical result, or invents a new useful theory. 
Prototype invention: This is when someone demonstrates some technological functionality in a lab setting.
Commercial invention: This is when a company creates a version of a technology that has sufficient functionality to achieve mass commercialization.
The line between 1 and 2 isnâ€™t especially important in my opinion, but the difference between 2 and 3 is the source of many arguments about who invented what. James Watt didnâ€™t build the first working steam engine [ https://substack.com/redirect/19469457-9bcb-4004-870e-84bb61caa3f6?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], nor Apple the first working smartphone [ https://substack.com/redirect/0db28998-1e08-4858-a27a-3a2986b50858?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], but they made critical improvements that made those technologies mass-marketable in forms that would be recognizable many years later. This leads some people to say that Watt and Apple donâ€™t deserve the credit for these inventions, but I think theyâ€™re wrong. Successful commercial invention requires bringing together a set of features, functional improvements, cost reductions, design, marketing/branding, and a business model for selling the thing, and so it involves a different set of skills than making a prototype in a lab. 
On the other hand, prototype invention is clearly important as well, because it demonstrates that something is possible to build. Everyone recognizes the Wright Brothers as the inventors of the airplane, even though they didnâ€™t make the kind of plane that a bunch of people wanted to buy and use.
So anyway, I tried to look up the answer to this question. My sources include A) Wikipediaâ€™s lists of Chinese inventions [ https://substack.com/redirect/55738e6e-cb5d-4aa7-930a-ca28ee7f1230?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] and discoveries [ https://substack.com/redirect/bac05110-3678-49c6-ab51-f7a1f01aeab7?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], Google searches, a conversation with Glenn Luk [ https://substack.com/redirect/8e646488-a433-4d4c-a419-9f6670617c9c?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] (who is very bullish on Chinese innovation), and a report by ChatGPTâ€™s â€œDeep Researchâ€ AI. 
In terms of commercial inventions like the smartphone or the steam engine, there are some big things that have come out of China since the turn of the century. These include:
1. The quadcopter drone
When people say â€œdroneâ€ these days, they usually donâ€™t mean things like Americaâ€™s Reaper or Iranâ€™s Shahed â€” things that run on fossil fuels. They mean battery-powered quadcopters. This type of drone has transformed our physical world much more than any other â€” arguably more than any piece of tech since the smartphone â€” and seen much wider commercial adoption. 
The first electronic remote-controlled quadcopter drones [ https://substack.com/redirect/99c1a0b5-4a3a-465f-997b-344a103fba32?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] were built by a Canadian company called Draganfly in the 1990s. A French company called Parrot released the first commercially successful quadcopter in 2010. But it wasnâ€™t until Chinaâ€™s DJI released their Phantom in 2013 that drones attained the baseline level of functionality we expect from them today, and took off as a popular global product. DJIâ€™s drones had better control, more stability, and longer flight time than Parrotâ€™s, as well as a number of additional features that we now see as crucial. 
So I think itâ€™s probably fine to call DJIâ€™s founder Frank Wang [ https://substack.com/redirect/0b075339-395e-43c1-9f88-b46a9b0e5034?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] (pictured at the top of this post) the inventor of the modern quadcopter drone, in the same way that Steve Jobs is generally regarded as the inventor of the iPhone. 
2. 5G wireless communications
5G isnâ€™t one thing â€” itâ€™s a product standard, meaning itâ€™s a suite of various wireless technologies and capabilities. But Chinese companies, especially Huawei and ZTE, led the world in terms of the integration of those various technologies. Those companies brought together technologies like Massive MIMO (a technique for using multiple antennas), beam forming (a way to transmit wireless data more directly and efficiently), and polar codes (a technique for noise reduction), they optimized and improved on these technologies, and they rolled them out effectively to consumers. 
So I think itâ€™s fair to say that Chinese companies â€œinvented 5Gâ€ in the same sense that Japanese companies invented 3G, or American companies invented 4G. 
3. The personal air taxi
Lots of companies have been working on these, but most people agree that the Chinese company Ehang was the first to commercialize these [ https://substack.com/redirect/8f56d3dd-0dee-4aef-b05b-d55c52542a53?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. They look pretty nifty:
4. The semi-solid state battery car and the sodium-ion battery car
Chinese car companies were the first to release vehicles powered by semi-solid state batteries [ https://substack.com/redirect/7dbd7544-48e8-4d7c-b97c-6957dad04104?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] and sodium-ion batteries [ https://substack.com/redirect/f682fdbb-80c1-4cd7-abb8-0f3338ee627a?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], two alternatives to the typical lithium-ion batteries we use in EVs. Each one offers some tradeoffs relative to the typical kind of electric car â€” sodium-ion batteries are a bit safer and charge faster, while semi-solid batteries have faster charging, better safety, higher energy density, and longer lifespans.
5. Dockless bike sharing
Bike sharing itself was invented elsewhere, but a Chinese company is generally believed to be the first to commercialize dockless bike sharing [ https://substack.com/redirect/3c7b13c6-891a-456a-b0f4-93c304b5f641?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], which has now become widespread [ https://substack.com/redirect/1c0615a0-bf44-4baf-b629-dbfb480d2efe?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] in the country. 
6. The foldable smartphone
The Royole FlexPai is generally acknowledged as the worldâ€™s first commercialized foldable smartphone. Itâ€™s pretty neat!
7. Face-scan payments
Chinaâ€™s Alipay was the first to implement â€œsmile to pay [ https://substack.com/redirect/e8fa15a6-ffce-44f9-943f-83f41dde158c?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]â€ systems, back in 2017.
8. The vape (e-cigarette)
This was actually invented back in 2003 [ https://substack.com/redirect/115458b5-1c8b-4d93-888c-ab05ac24fe1b?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], by a Chinese pharmacist named Hon Lik.
9. The skyscraper building machine (and various other construction machinery)
This is pretty awesome. A Chinese company created a machine [ https://substack.com/redirect/930a39c2-93df-40af-92a4-faf05ffa6adc?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] that moves up a skyscraper as itâ€™s constructed, building each floor as it goes:
There are also some pretty cool original machines for laying high speed rail track [ https://substack.com/redirect/c0456c73-2ecd-4ca7-b6f6-871329f2b42c?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. 
10. Electromagnetic car suspension
This was invented a long time ago by Bose, but BYD appears to be finally bringing it to market:
Those are the main commercial inventions I could find. Iâ€™m sure this isnâ€™t a complete list, because A) there are a few things that are probably known inside of China but not well-known in English-language media yet (Iâ€™ve heard rumors that Chinese chip companies are already mass-producing 3D DRAM [ https://substack.com/redirect/9400422d-55d2-4ec3-85bb-a014ee8a7c4a?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], for instance), and B) there are some inventions that will end up being important but whose importance people havenâ€™t generally realized yet (like the air conditioner in 1902). 
Also, this list might soon expand. Chinese companies might soon come out with the worldâ€™s first marketable humanoid robots [ https://substack.com/redirect/fbfff790-3c9d-48ef-a6c2-0d4ca5162050?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], solid-state car batteries [ https://substack.com/redirect/fc080c43-799b-485b-b6eb-931bd6d10f7e?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], vacuum maglev trains [ https://substack.com/redirect/7256bf22-6aa2-4406-b7e0-505f866a62b3?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] (â€œhyperloopâ€), thorium nuclear reactors [ https://substack.com/redirect/ee82260d-c93c-48ba-b31e-d4c3011b2fbf?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], perovskite solar cells [ https://substack.com/redirect/b917d634-f3ed-46c4-9f4f-bdd5092560e6?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], lab-grown organs [ https://substack.com/redirect/697c8164-6062-43c0-92f1-efa7e2af9e20?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], etc. These technologies have been in development for a while, and while any one of them would represent a game-changing invention, it has never been clear how far they were from mass-market adoption. 
So if you can think of anything else that should go on this list, please let me know.
But even allowing for the incompleteness of this list, I feel like I expected it to beâ€¦a little more impressive? Drones are amazing, and are already changing the world, but some of the other items here seem a little bit marginal. Dockless bike-sharing is neat, but Iâ€™m not sure how big of a difference it makes in terms of transportation convenience relative to the docked variety. Foldable smartphones are cool, but will you really buy one? Sodium-ion and semi-solid-state battery cars have some advantages, but seem likely to end up as niche products. Facial recognition payment doesnâ€™t really save you much time versus swiping a phone, and itâ€™s a little creepy. A couple of commonly mentioned items, like BYDâ€™s â€œblade batteryâ€ [ https://substack.com/redirect/cc445196-7be5-4712-9256-c1674fe96ccf?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], seemed so incremental that I didnâ€™t even put them on this list.
Anyway, prototype inventions are a bit harder to identify, because unless theyâ€™re done in an academic lab, itâ€™s hard to tell how well the prototype really works. Companies tend to be tight-lipped about what they invent, especially in China where other companies are always trying to steal their IP. And what you do see publicly released [ https://substack.com/redirect/778fd946-ad14-4469-9946-de945fd8763e?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] is often a marketing stunt that doesnâ€™t really reveal how well the thing works. Then there are military inventions, which are kept under even tighter wraps [ https://substack.com/redirect/41c90464-ca3b-4234-b068-6e4ef5ab94bd?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. Even when you know that a Chinese company has a working prototype of a humanoid robot, or a solid-state battery car, or a vacuum maglev, itâ€™s not clear whether they got there first in any meaningful sense.
The Wright Brothers were sort of a special case here â€” everyone could see for themselves that the thing flew. 
As for scientific discoveries, here Iâ€™m having a lot of trouble constructing a list. The top ones I could find include:
1. The creation of space-based quantum communications [ https://substack.com/redirect/d290283e-ce7c-4453-b16a-18f19b0040e9?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] (useful for telling when your communications have been compromised) 
2. The first cloned primates [ https://substack.com/redirect/46f25efe-0bbb-441e-b492-85bc6e949b5b?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]
3. The first photonic quantum computer [ https://substack.com/redirect/15c2927a-61a1-4f3c-b702-41a0dd647cf4?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] to demonstrate â€œquantum supremacyâ€
4. The first human babies whose genes were edited [ https://substack.com/redirect/2640d50c-9b92-478c-8a10-dc72d9f27601?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] using Crispr (though the scientist was jailed for doing this) 
Thereâ€™s reallyâ€¦not much else. Not being a scientist, Iâ€™m not really able to judge how groundbreaking a discovery in chemistry or materials science or biology is. But AI, Wikipedia, and the lists I find online are having real trouble listing Chinese achievements in science that arenâ€™t of the form â€œworldâ€™s biggest radio telescopeâ€ or â€œfastest supercomputer on Earth for six monthsâ€. Wikipediaâ€™s list [ https://substack.com/redirect/bac05110-3678-49c6-ab51-f7a1f01aeab7?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] of modern Chinese discoveries is almost all math theorems from the mid 20th century (usually work done outside China). 
Again, if there are big ones Iâ€™m missing, please let me know!
This is a little strange, right? Chinese scientists are publishing 80% of the worldâ€™s high-impact papers in materials science, 75% in chemistry, and almost 60% in physics, and neither I nor the entire English-speaking internet can find more than one or two breakthrough advances coming out of China in these fields? 
The answer here canâ€™t be â€œChinese science is fakeâ€. I mean, a bit of it is fake [ https://substack.com/redirect/9eada355-5ced-4979-9f56-f4a9aa4fe267?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], because of citation rings and perverse incentives at Chinese universities, but most of it is very real. Itâ€™s just all incremental stuff. The weight of all those incremental discoveries is certainly world-changing, but so far there have been startlingly few big breakthroughs. 
The seeming paucity of Chinese invention and discovery is even stranger when we consider how much human capital the country has. With 1.4 billion people, one of the worldâ€™s best education systems (at least in the richer regions), and incredibly well-funded universities, the country should be producing more Nobel-caliber scientists. The talent is there. Except when you hear about Chinese scientists making world-changing discoveries, they all seem to have done their work outside China [ https://substack.com/redirect/ec7774c8-1d24-4e63-9539-322ec2d9dd5d?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], often in the U.S.
Now, Iâ€™m always very wary of the stereotype that Asian countries are uncreative. This stereotype got lobbed at Japan for a long time, but it was never true; a list of Japanese inventions and discoveries [ https://substack.com/redirect/0113ee8b-6c5a-4a2c-81c5-a63cbb0c6381?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] will run for many pages. Yes, there were cases in which Japanese companies adopted and improved technology from the U.S. and Europe â€” CNC machine tools, shipbuilding, and fuel-efficient cars come to mind â€” but at the same time, Japanese scientists and inventors made breakthroughs at about the same rate as their counterparts in the West. The â€œJapan is uncreativeâ€ trope partly came from Japanâ€™s slightly later industrialization, but was also a defensive coping reaction by American businesses in the 70s and 80s who were afraid of Japanese competition. 
But the stereotype does seem to fit some smaller Asian countries a bit better. Singapore, especially, is notorious for having some of the worldâ€™s best scientists and engineers, but very few breakthrough discoveries [ https://substack.com/redirect/756a7d58-e372-4905-a02e-6ac4dbc0473b?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. The same is true of Taiwan [ https://substack.com/redirect/b041a3fc-5a01-4ee6-b590-9032f19ba293?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. South Korea is somewhere in between â€” there are a few standout Korean inventions [ https://substack.com/redirect/2dcdf81b-1ae3-48cd-bf67-56416226cd84?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], but so far no science Nobels and few game-changing products. Together those three countries have 80 million people â€” about 2/3 of Japanâ€™s population â€” and yet together theyâ€™ve produced far fewer breakthroughs than Japan. 
The good news here is that a country doesnâ€™t actually have to produce a bunch of standout inventions and Nobel-winning scientific discoveries in order to get rich. Singapore, Korea, and Taiwan all have higher per capita GDP [ https://substack.com/redirect/d9063ccd-fd8c-44f7-bff6-df29b842fe74?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] than Japan does. So the question of â€œWhere are all the Chinese breakthroughs?â€ might ultimately not matter to Chinaâ€™s leaders. Being â€œgiant Koreaâ€ or â€œgiant Taiwanâ€ doesnâ€™t sound like a particularly bad fate. 
Still, I do wonder why China, with its vast talent pool, its avalanche of research funding, and its huge consumer markets, hasnâ€™t produced more game-changing inventions and discoveries yet. I really doubt itâ€™s a function of autocracy â€” the CCP would surely reward a Chinese researcher for inventing mRNA vaccines or the transformer model or Crispr. And Frank Wang wasnâ€™t punished for inventing the modern quadcopter drone â€” in fact, heâ€™s a billionaire, and seems to be escaping the negative attention that peers like Jack Ma have received. 
One possibility is that Chinaâ€™s economic institutions reward fast-following and intense competition over breakthrough innovation. The lack of strong intellectual property protection might make it economically pointless to invent something really new â€” itâ€™ll just get copied by someone else who takes all the money. That seems like it would encourage more incremental advances. In science, incentives for quantity of papers over quality [ https://substack.com/redirect/2af3a163-0355-424d-bce7-a799179db4ec?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] might be the culprit. These incentives, along with various industrial policies, might produce intensive overcompetition, which I believe Chinese people call â€œneijuan [ https://substack.com/redirect/327d0844-ca63-4483-bf8f-d9d66cc0f404?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]â€. 
Whether China can tweak its system to produce more breakthrough discoveries and inventions is an open question. Whether it should even care about doing so, given the success of countries like Singapore, Taiwan, and Korea, is another open question. The country certainly does tons of innovation, and maybe the incremental kind is all you really need.
But if the scarcity of breakthroughs persists, I think thereâ€™s the possibility that, between that and Chinaâ€™s censorship of art and culture, 21st century great powers might simply turn out to be a bit more boring than their 20th century predecessors.

Unsubscribe https://substack..eGnh0ydZiHZj70erQR0VDagl5f8zuCy7bmA0HaYPpFk?

subject: I Asked 5 AI to Predict 2025â€Šâ€”â€ŠHereâ€™s What They Said & Why They Said It | Ritvik Nayak in Generative AI

A guest piece by Afra [ https://substack.com/@afrawang ], freelance writer and podcaster [ https://substack.com/redirect/d1d0c8e0-a802-4035-b175-0a5125a7711c?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] [Jordan: I highly recommend this show!] with working experience in tech and crypto. Personal site here [ https://substack.com/redirect/8014230f-9395-4b7a-ac22-58da28c46fc3?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ].
DeepSeekâ€™s winds have already been blowing for some time, but this particular gale seems to have real staying power.
President Trump characterized DeepSeek as â€œa wake-up call, [ https://substack.com/redirect/9194cd34-25a8-4291-ae71-902504a461e5?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]â€ Scale AI CEO Alexandr Wang called it â€œearth-shattering [ https://substack.com/redirect/c017eb60-8362-45cb-b439-26da7f672e3f?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ],â€ and Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei deigned to come on ChinaTalk to discuss fears of powerful AI within â€œauthoritarian systems of government [ https://open.substack.com/pub/chinatalk/p/anthropics-dario-amodei-on-ai-competition?r=1bqgb&selection=4b99f263-7b8c-47a3-af62-5ffa8259a513&utm_campaign=post-share-selection&utm_medium=web ].â€
On Chinese social media, the discussions took on a life of their own, with the most popular use case being the calculation of oneâ€™s Ba Zi (å…«å­—) and astrological chart, using the social media tag â€œAIç„å­¦â€ (AI Mysticism). Users werenâ€™t just seeking their personal fortunes â€” they saw the nationâ€™s destiny itself shifting through DeepSeekâ€™s emergence. These conversations are a swirling mix of collective jubilation, national pride, and gleeful satisfaction over Americaâ€™s â€œChina envy,â€ often accompanied by playful banter.
Yet amidst this discourse, a deeper and more resonant question emerges: could this be a sign of Chinaâ€™s technological ascension? Is this evidence that Guoyun (å›½è¿) â€” the nationâ€™s long-awaited destiny â€” has finally arrived?
First, what is Guoyun å›½è¿ï¼Ÿ
The term å›½è¿ combines two characters: å›½ (guÃ³, â€œnation/stateâ€) and è¿ (yÃ¹n, â€œfate/destiny/fortuneâ€). This concept emerged from traditional Chinese cosmological thinking, where the destiny of the state was seen as intertwined with celestial patterns and dynastic cycles. This term, once confined to the ornate dialogue of period dramas set in imperial China, has begun to surface with increasing frequency on my social media timeline.
The Guoyun narrative around DeepSeek began when Feng Ji å†¯éª¥, creator of the globally successful game â€œBlack Myth: Wukong,â€ declared it a â€œnational destiny-level technological achievement [ https://open.substack.com/pub/chinatalk/p/deepseek-the-view-from-china?r=1bqgb&selection=ff4b70f5-70ee-49ca-9a4b-4b160ee559b3&utm_campaign=post-share-selection&utm_medium=web ].â€
The discourse gained momentum when Zhou Hongyi å‘¨é¸¿ç¥, Chairperson of Qihoo 360, positioned DeepSeek as a key player in Chinaâ€™s â€œAI Avengers Team [ https://open.substack.com/pub/chinatalk/p/deepseek-the-view-from-china?r=1bqgb&selection=3bd67d83-4391-434a-bb22-86d655c17ce9&utm_campaign=post-share-selection&utm_medium=web ]â€ against U.S. dominance. This sentiment echoed across media, with headlines like â€œIs DeepSeek a breakthrough of national destiny? The picture could be bigger [ https://substack.com/redirect/29f03efc-18eb-4b0f-9bf1-46afa0a55f3d?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]â€ and â€œDeepSeek triggers U.S. stock plunge; can it really change the nationâ€™s destiny? [ https://substack.com/redirect/29f03efc-18eb-4b0f-9bf1-46afa0a55f3d?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]"
For Chinese netizens, discussions about politics on social media are often marked by subtlety and veneration with trepidation (for reasons that require little explanation). However, during the 2025 Chinese New Year, the discourse expanded far beyond politics and DeepSeek into a cacophony of cultural euphoria â€”a wave of self-congratulatory enthusiasm that evolved into something larger culturally. This included the movie Nezha 2,  [ https://substack.com/redirect/bd88f21e-d1ff-4164-9b23-b8ad0635ef2d?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]which shattered box office records and surpassed Inside Out 2 to become the highest-grossing animated film of all time (with patriotism-fueled consumption boosting the box office performance), TikTok refugees flooding Xiaohongshu [ https://substack.com/redirect/657a5c25-beff-4c8a-8d49-36fb69e8426a?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], and advanced Unitree robotics performing during the Spring Festival Gala [ https://substack.com/redirect/79739fc3-8b0b-41ff-80fc-23602640e5de?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ]. These achievements seemed to occur against a historical backdrop where technological and cultural advances carry deeper significance about Chinaâ€™s rightful place in the cosmic order.
The Guoyun discourse extends beyond tech leaders, media commentary, and social media posts.
President Xi Jinping has woven the concept of destiny into official rhetoric, though carefully stripped of its more superstitious elements. Speaking at the 19th Academician Conference of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in May 2018, Xi declared [ https://substack.com/redirect/9a26efa9-5ff6-4d27-84e1-7aac94e958fe?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], â€œInnovation determines the future; reform concerns national destiny. The field of science and technology is the area most in need of continuous reform åˆ›æ–°å†³èƒœæœªæ¥ï¼Œæ”¹é©å…³ä¹å›½è¿ã€‚ç§‘æŠ€é¢†åŸŸæ˜¯æœ€éœ€è¦ä¸æ–­æ”¹é©çš„é¢†åŸŸ.â€ This statement aligns with his broader techno-nationalist vision, explicitly linking technological advancement to Chinaâ€™s strategic future.
A 2024 Peopleâ€™s Daily [ https://substack.com/redirect/0640f150-f53d-4817-8c91-cd0ade6e5f93?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] article discussing Xiâ€™s thoughts emphasized that â€œcultural confidence is a major issue concerning national destiny åšå®šæ–‡åŒ–è‡ªä¿¡ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªäº‹å…³å›½è¿å…´è¡°...çš„å¤§é—®é¢˜"ã€‚
This rhetorical shift signals a carefully calibrated blend of traditional Chinese concepts with modern governance â€” a bridge between ancient ideas of dynastic cycles and contemporary aspirations for technological supremacy.
Beyond superstition: is this a collective myth-making or post-pandemic yearning for certainty?
It would be a mistake to dismiss this discourse as mere superstition or propaganda.
The COVID-19 pandemic marked a watershed moment in Chinese societyâ€™s relationship with national destiny. To me, Zero COVID became a mirror polished to cruel clarity, reflecting a China I no longer recognized. During the rigid cycles of lockdowns and reopenings, I didnâ€™t see my parents for two years, my grandmother was hospitalized, and my cousin was confined to his university dorm for three whole months culminating in a severe mental breakdown. Friends lost loved ones due to a lack of timely treatment options. Back then, seeing how waves of people wanted to â€œrun (æ¶¦)â€ from China, I thought for the first time that I might never return to China, and that I might become part of the Chinese diaspora forever.
COVID created a collective trauma that many Chinese are still processing.
But this experience has paradoxically reinforced a certain earnest faith in Chinaâ€™s future among ordinary citizens. The optimism in the discussion of Guoyun might represent a complex emotional response to the uncertainty and trauma from the COVID era â€” a blend of traditional fatalism with genuine aspirations. Having weathered the pandemicâ€™s disruption, many ordinary Chinese seek reassurance about the future through familiar cultural frameworks. â€˜National Destinyâ€™ provides exactly that â€” itâ€™s a narrative that contextualizes current struggles within a larger, ultimately triumphant story. Itâ€™s therapeutic.
The discourse around å›½è¿è®º (guÃ³yÃ¹n lÃ¹n, or â€œnational destiny theoryâ€) reveals parallels to Americaâ€™s historical myth-making. Perhaps the most striking similarity between China and the US is their unwavering belief in their own exceptionalism and their destined special place in the world order. While America has Manifest Destiny and the Frontier Thesis, Chinaâ€™s â€œnational rejuvenationâ€ serves as its own foundational myth from which people can derive self-confidence. Through countless repetitions across state and social media, this narrative has become deeply ingrained in Chinaâ€™s national consciousness.
The wounds behind techno-nationalism
Where myths nurture the national consciousness, technology has become the battleground where Chinaâ€™s historical narrative demands its vindication. The roots of Chinaâ€™s techno-nationalism run deep, drawing emotional power from Chinaâ€™s â€œcentury of humiliation.â€ U.S. actions â€” chip controls, the attempted TikTok ban, tariffs, investigations of Chinese scientists, and suspicions of Chinese espionage [ https://substack.com/redirect/485e1103-d272-4d9d-ad37-2e4880fa665d?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] â€” rekindle the historical trauma of humiliation.
For decades, China has been portrayed as a mere copycat or thief of Western innovation. Each technological breakthrough now serves as vindication, a refutation of that dismissive narrative â€” this shame has never truly been resolved. As Kevin Xu elaborated [ https://substack.com/@kevinsxu/note/c-89171508?utm_source=notes-share-action&r=1bqgb ] on DeepSeekâ€™s open-sourced nature, â€œItâ€™s all for the validation and approval,â€ â€” a sharp acknowledgment that when Chinese engineers share their code with the world, theyâ€™re not just demonstrating technical prowess but seeking to heal a wound in the national psyche:
In the Chinese open source community, there is this thing that I would call open source â€œzealâ€ or â€œcallingâ€ (å¼€æºæƒ…æ€€)
Most engineers are thrilled if their open source projects â€” a database, a container registry, etc-- are used by a foreign company, especially a silicon valley one. Theyâ€™d tack on free labor on top of already free software, to fix bugs, resolve issues, all day all night. Itâ€™s all for the validation and approval.
Implicit in this â€œzealâ€ or â€œcallingâ€ is an acute awareness that no one in the West respects what they do because everything in China is stolen or created by cheating. They are also aware that Chinese firms have been taking for free lots of open source tech to advance, but they want to create their own, contribute, and prove that their tech is good enough to be taken for free by foreign firms -- some nationalism, some engineering pride.
So if you want to really understand why DeepSeek does what it does and open source everything, start there. Itâ€™s not a political statement, not to troll Stargate or Trump inauguration, or to help their quant fundâ€™s shorts on NVDA (though if that were the case, itâ€™d be quite brilliant and savage)
The drive to prove oneself on behalf of the nation is expressed vividly in Chinese popular culture. I couldnâ€™t stop thinking about Illumine Linga (ä¸´é«˜å¯æ˜), an open-source collaborative novel that has captivated Chinaâ€™s engineering community and become a phenomenon of its own. The story follows modern Chinese engineers who time-travel to the declining Ming dynasty, right before China was conquered by the Manchus, bringing industrial equipment and technical knowledge. They gradually industrialize Hainan and Guangdong provinces before expanding outward with the ultimate goal of establishing global hegemony.
Though ostensibly just fiction, Illumine Linga pulses with the heartbeat of Chinaâ€™s â€œIndustrial Partyâ€ (å·¥ä¸šå…š) â€” that loose constellation of engineers, programmers, and technically-minded patriots united by an almost religious faith in technology as destinyâ€™s instrument. The novel serves as a sharp allegory for contemporary aspirations: technological mastery as the path to national resurrection and global respect.
In the Western intellectual tradition, technology and data have undergone phases of detached scrutiny â€” viewed first as tools of emancipation, and later as vectors of control. Foucaultâ€™s panopticon mutated into Zuboffâ€™s surveillance capitalism; Wienerâ€™s Cybernetics birthed both Silicon Valley and Snowdenâ€™s disclosures. This academic back-and-forth assumes a fundamental premise: technology can theoretically exist as a neutral substrate awaiting ideological imprint.
However, in my impression, Chinaâ€™s techno-discourse never evinces such â€œpurity.â€
From its inception, technology has been semantically encased in the shell of techno-nationalism. In Chinaâ€™s history textbooks, Qian Xuesenâ€™s missiles for the Two Bombs, One Satellite program were never just missiles, but brushstrokes in the narrative of â€œstanding up again.â€ Yuan Longpingâ€™s hybrid rice strains didnâ€™t merely feed millions; they were genetic correctives to the â€œCentury of Humiliation,â€ each harvest a quiet refutation of the colonial-era belief that China couldnâ€™t innovate.
On Chinese New Yearâ€™s Eve, a fake response [ https://substack.com/redirect/26e56bcc-176e-44c6-8c1f-19ca38a27f00?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] to the â€œnational destiny theoryâ€ attributed to Liang Wenfeng circulated widely online, with many believing and sharing it as authentic. This response claimed that DeepSeekâ€™s open-source decision was merely â€œstanding on the shoulders of giants, adding a few more screws to the edifice of Chinaâ€™s large language models,â€ and that the true national destiny resided in â€œa group of stubborn fools using code as bricks and algorithms as steel, building bridges to the future.â€ This fake statementâ€”notably devoid of wolf warrior rhetoricâ€”spread virally, its humility and relentless spirit embodying some values people hoped Chinese technologists would champion. Meanwhile, the real Liang Wenfeng remained silent after DeepSeekâ€™s rise. A month later, he appeared on CCTV sitting beside Tencentâ€™s Ma Huateng at Xi Jinpingâ€™s symposium [ https://open.substack.com/pub/chinatalk/p/xis-hard-tech-avengers?r=1bqgb&selection=dc394f84-886a-4f9a-8394-f72f7c90acb9&utm_campaign=post-share-selection&utm_medium=web ] for top business leaders.
The publicâ€™s fascination with Liang showed no signs of waning. In Silicon Valley, his previous interviews were swiftly translated into English and meticulously analyzed, while in China, his rise also inspired mystical interpretationsâ€”during the Spring Festival holiday, Liang Wenfengâ€™s ancestral home in Zhanjiang, Guangdong transformed into an impromptu tourist attraction, drawing feng shui masters eager to study the geomantic properties of his family residence.
Humans have always sought ways to calculate the incalculable. Perhaps thatâ€™s what makes the conversation around Guoyun so captivating: itâ€™s not just about predicting the future, but about sense-making in Chinaâ€™s present.

subject: Cutting health care â€œwasteâ€ is hard
body:
View this post on the web at https://www.slowboring.com/p/cutting-health-care-waste-is-hard

Iâ€™m happy to concede that â€œwasteful spendingâ€ is, in fact, a real thing and that making the government more efficient is genuinely desirable, even as DOGE wreaks havoc on the American state and it becomes increasingly clear that efficiency isnâ€™t actually the goal of Donald Trump or Elon Musk. 
Itâ€™s worth thinking about what it would mean to take this seriously, especially because we may need to reconstruct many of our institutions in the future and should try to build back better. The foreign aid case strikes me as particularly clear-cut in this regard [ https://substack.com/redirect/e5ba42ce-c8aa-4b07-aa9f-971dc6bd1a90?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] â€” some programs are dramatically more cost effective than others, and a sane administration would cut the ineffective ones in order to put more money behind highly effective ideas. 
Everything DOGE has focused on so far is nickel-and-dime stuff, though. In fiscal terms, what really matters is defense, Social Security, and health programs. Social Security is already extremely efficient, in the sense that itâ€™s basically cash transfers with low overhead. Defense is its own kettle of fish. 
But I think itâ€™s worth talking specifically about healthcare, where many hundreds of billions of dollars (arguably more) are spent on an incredibly wide array of programs and services. Itâ€™s obviously not the case that all of these expenditures have equally high-impact outcomes, and in any reasonable system, we would periodically review whatâ€™s actually happening and try to eliminate waste. 
At the same time, the question of what waste means in a health care context is fraught. 
Itâ€™s different from what it means in the context of something like the energy efficiency tax credits created by the Inflation Reduction Act [ https://substack.com/redirect/f22729dc-3252-47ac-9c2a-25f4bf0f6540?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ].  The question of how much greenhouse gas emission reduction per dollar we get from subsidizing heat pump water heaters is somewhat difficult to answer empirically, and Iâ€™m sure that people disagree about it. But conceptually, itâ€™s pretty clear what weâ€™re trying to measure. You can, in principle, measure the cost-effectiveness of those tax credits and compare it to the cost-effectiveness of electric car tax credits and see which one is better. Because whether or not you, personally, think itâ€™s a good idea to spend money on reducing greenhouse gas emissions, itâ€™s at least clear what the program is trying to do. 
Health care spending, for better or worse, is much more conceptually complicated. 
The specter of death panels
A lot of health care spending goes toward care for elderly people. 
The way human beings work is that, notwithstanding Bryan Johnsonâ€™s best efforts [ https://substack.com/redirect/44c450c1-e351-49fb-a2ee-5bf8476ca2e0?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ], we die. According to the Social Security Administration, the life expectancy for a 90-year-old man is less than four years [ https://substack.com/redirect/fbe20d7b-23d8-46df-a012-b0535f7b5bd4?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ] and for a woman of the same age, itâ€™s less than five. As a result, the aggregate impact on the life expectancy of providing health care to people over the age of 90 is miniscule. If we categorically denied all health care to nonagenarians, how much could life expectancy possibly fall?
And itâ€™s not just a question of money â€” real resources, including hospital beds and the time and labor of skilled professionals, are used in caring for the very old, and those resources could instead be put toward other health care goals. 
Of course, nobody is proposing that, exactly. But thereâ€™s certainly a sense in which that kind of move would be efficient. 
Budget wonks used to talk a lot about the very high level of health spending that people tend to incur during their final year of life [ https://substack.com/redirect/dd3434bf-6616-4356-a7ff-d00a2c45d7a2?j=eyJ1IjoiM3NieW8zIn0.qiOB1DEStwFdQU4w7pOLi8ROs-5FWNiMeyk314rEV4Y ].
